text: If you’ve ever had a headache, then you know
the wonders of one of the United States’s most popular
over the counter medicines, Tylenol.
Also known as acetaminophen, or if you’re overseas,
paracetamol, this stuff is a quick and easy way
to relieve pain and reduce fever.
Although you may be confident in the fact that your
pharmacy knows everything there is to know about
this stuff, take a look at the physician’s note
that comes with the bottle:
“Although the analgesic effect of acetaminophen
is well established, the site and mode of action
have not been clearly elucidated.”
Translation: Yeah, this stuff works,
but we just don’t know how.
However, there are some working theories.
Theory 1:
Acetaminophen blocks an enzyme that sends
out chemicals called prostaglandins
that make our bodies feel pain.
If this theory is correct, then acetaminophen
works very similarly to Aspirin, Advil, and Aleve.
Theory 2:
Some research is leading into showing that
acetaminophen works on the endocannabinoid system,
which has a role in the sensation of pain in the body.
Cannabinoid sound familiar?
The main drug in Marijuana, THC,
also works through this system.
This is why people look to marijuana
as an option for pain relief.
Theory 3:
Acetaminophen may also possibly make adjustments
to signaling from the neurotransmitter serotonin.
Serotonin’s connection to pain is complicated—some
wasps and scorpions have serotonin in their venom,
and serotonin levels may even play
a role in migraine headaches.
While all these theories seem very different,
some researchers out there think that it isn’t
necessarily true that there is just one process, but
instead, a combination of all three of these processes.
Chemists want to know how acetaminophen work so
they can create better pain relief medicine.
Today it’s one of the most popular drugs in the U.S.
with over twenty-seven billon doses sold out in 2009.
When taken at recommended levels,
Tylenol is a perfectly safe pain reliever,
but watch out, if you go overboard,
acetaminophen isn’t as safe as you think.
Acetaminophen poisoning is one of the most
common forms of drug toxicity in the world.
Many prescriptions and over the counter drugs contain
this stuff, so it’s easy for people seeking quick pain relief
to accidentally take too much without realizing it.
Overdosing on acetaminophen can lad to liver damage,
liver failure, or even death.
When you take this drug your body produces
a chemical byproduct or a metabolite.
When too much of this stuff builds up,
it can damage your liver cell.
So seriously people, read the darn label
and pay attention to dosage.
If your still not sure about dozing
ask your doctor or your pharmacist.
The sooner we figure out how acetaminophen works,
the sooner scientists can create better,
safer pain relief medicines.
For more in depth information about this
Tylenol conundrum, look down there in
the video description for a link to a
C&EN article in the subject by Carmen Drahl.
Also get your food science on with your videos
about garlic breath and the other
about how caffeine effects your brain.
Thanks for watching folks,
and don't forget to subscribe.
